results.headline: In London, the Walls Have Eyes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Closed Circuit

results.summary_short: In “Closed Circuit,” by John Crowley, two London lawyers’ professional lives become muddied by a shared past.

results.headline: They Probably Should Have Skipped This Dinner Party

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of You're Next

results.summary_short: “You’re Next,” by Adam Wingard, has masked killers with crossbows and a plot full of surprises.

results.headline: Style and Kinetics Triumph in a Turbulent China

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Grandmaster

results.summary_short: Wong Kar-wai’s “Grandmaster” is a film about Ip Man, a 20th-century Chinese martial arts legend, but also an exploration of opposing forces like loyalty and love.

results.headline: Havana Fantasies, Biology and Geography

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Una Noche

results.summary_short: Three teenagers plot to flee to Miami from Cuba in “Una Noche,” the feature directorial debut of Lucy Mulloy.

results.headline: When It’s All About the Timing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Drinking Buddies

results.summary_short: Joe Swanberg’s new romance, “Drinking Buddies,” reveals, among other things, that passive-aggression is nowadays less a personal trait than a cultural norm.

results.headline: Fools Rush In, With Camera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Devil's Pass

results.summary_short: In Renny Harlin’s “Devil’s Pass,” American students investigate a Russian skiing disaster shrouded in mystery.

results.headline: Last Call for Friends to Grow Up

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The World's End

results.summary_short: In “World’s End,” five British men reprise a pub crawl they had tried but failed to finish more than 20 years earlier as teenagers.

results.headline: One of His Biggest Fights Was Outside of the Ring

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Trials of Muhammad Ali

results.summary_short: “The Trials of Muhammad Ali” traces the road to Mr. Ali’s refusal in 1967 to serve in the Vietnam War, which cost him his license to box.

results.headline: What Happens When You’re Repeatedly Hit in the Head

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The United States of Football

results.summary_short: The documentary “The United States of Football” follows retired players dealing with dementia and depression after a career of hard knocks.

results.headline: People as the Big Game in an Alaskan Hunt

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Frozen Ground

results.summary_short: “The Frozen Ground,” starring Nicolas Cage, is a film about a serial killer and the investigator whose pursuit eventually pays off.

results.headline: A Plumber Lends a Sympathetic Ear

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sparrows Dance

results.summary_short: In Noah Buschel’s “Sparrows Dance,” an agoraphobic actress is forced to call upon the assistance of a poetry-writing handyman.

results.headline: Caretakers Needing Some Care Themselves

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Short Term 12

results.summary_short: “Short Term 12” is set at a group home inhabited by troubled adolescents and workers with issues.

results.headline: Drunk, Ornery and With a Gun in His Hands

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Savannah

results.summary_short: “Savannah” tells the story of a well-born Southerner who turns his back on privilege to hunt ducks with a former slave.

results.headline: That Fractious Couple, Sex and Religion

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paradise: Faith

results.summary_short: “Paradise: Faith,” the second film in a trilogy by the Austrian director Ulrich Seidl, examines the bleak relationship between a Roman Catholic missionary and her paraplegic Muslim husband.

results.headline: Privileged, but Wired Not to Find Comfort

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Thérèse

results.summary_short: “Thérèse,” set in 1920s France, revolves around an upper-class woman for whom happiness is elusive.

results.headline: The Desert Foils Friendly Scheming

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scenic Route

results.summary_short: Friends are stranded in the desert in “Scenic Route,” directed by the brothers Kevin and Michael Goetz.

results.headline: This Higher Education in Argentina Is All Politics

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Student

results.summary_short: In Santiago Mitre’s “Estudiante,” a university student in Buenos Aires ends up learning more outside the classroom.

results.summary_short: In “The Mortal Instruments,” a new Shadowhunter — part human, part angel — is recruited into the battle to rid New York of demons (and perhaps short shorts).

results.headline: A Daughter’s Visit Turns Into a Family Stress Test

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Old Cats

results.summary_short: In “Old Cats,” a troubled daughter’s strained relationship with her elderly mother plays out in a Chilean apartment.
